The point is that college produce both knowledge and graduates. The markets for these gods are quite different, while the quality of the producer depends on both. The market for knowledge has been disrupted by the internet so much so that publications costs will reach  zero in a few years. However, demand (from government and privat sector) keeps the prices artificially up by subsidies and patents. For graduates, technology also plays a role. Most degrees will be rendered useless in a few years. This will increase the cost of college and this will cost be pass on to consumers (again government and private sector). High demand is positive, the problem is the supply side. Innovation should not cost a lot of money. Studies with few demand should naturally died out. Any claim that studies have a value by their own and not determined by demand, is subjective. In conclusion, we need to separate the college that operates from demand from the subjective one.

Another Alleged Transitional Form: Archæopteryx...

According to evolutionists, some small dinosaurs, such as Velociraptors or Dromeosaurs, evolved by acquiring wings and then starting to fly. Thus, Archæopteryx is assumed to be a transitional form that branched off from its dinosaur ancestors and started to fly for the first time. This imaginary tale appears in almost all evolutionist publications.

Evolutionists pronounce the name of one single creature in response. This is the fossil of a bird called Archæopteryx, one of the most widely-known so-called transitional forms among the very few that evolutionists still defend.

rchæopteryx, the so-called ancestor of present-day birds according to evolutionists, lived approximately 150 million years ago. The theory holds that some small dinosaurs, such as Velociraptors or Dromeosaurs, evolved by acquiring wings and then starting to fly. Thus, Archæopteryx is assumed to be a transitional form that branched off from its dinosaur ancestors and started to fly for the first time.

However, the latest studies of Archæopteryx fossils indicate that this creature is absolutely not a transitional form, but an extinct species of bird, having some insignificant differences from present-day birds.

The thesis that Archæopteryx was a "half-bird" that could not fly perfectly was popular among evolutionist circles until not long ago. The absence of a sternum (breastbone) in this creature was held up as the most important evidence that this bird could not fly properly. (The sternum is a bone found under the thorax to which the muscles required for flight are attached. In our day, this breastbone is observed in all flying and non-flying birds, and even in bats, a flying mammal which belongs to a very different family.)

However, the seventh Archæopteryx fossil, which was found in 1992, caused great astonishment among evolutionists. The reason was that in this recently discovered fossil, the breastbone that was long assumed by evolutionists to be missing was discovered to have existed after all. This fossil was described in Nature magazine as follows:

The recently discovered seventh specimen of the Archæopteryx preserves a partial, rectangular sternum, long suspected but never previously documented. This attests to its strong flight muscles.47

This discovery invalidated the mainstay of the claims that Archæopteryx was a half-bird that could not fly properly.

Moreover, the structure of the bird's feathers became one of the most important pieces of evidence confirming that Archæopteryx was a flying bird in the real sense. The asymmetric feather structure of Archæopteryx is indistinguishable from that of birds living today, and indicates that it could fly perfectly well. As the eminent paleontologist Carl O. Dunbar states, "because of its feathers [Archæopteryx is] distinctly to be classed as a bird." 48

Another fact that was revealed by the structure of Archæopteryx's feathers was its warm-blooded metabolism. As was discussed above, reptiles and dinosaurs are cold-blooded animals whose body heat fluctuates with the temperature of their environment, rather than being homeostatically regulated. A very important function of the feathers on birds is the maintenance of a constant body temperature. The fact that Archæopteryx had feathers showed that it was a real, warm-blooded bird that needed to regulate its body heat, in contrast to dinosaurs.

Marx's economic theory, like the work of any other great philosopher past or present, is of course deeply flawed in certain places, some of them crucial to his conclusions. That said, his critique of capitalism is spot on and doesn't depend on anything so esoteric as the densest theoretical chapters of Capital. More people should read him given how quickly global capitalism seems to be careening toward the abyss.

The biggest flaw in his theory is the lack of the concept of risk. Profit is the reward for taking the risk, not from exploitation of the labors. The assumption of Marxism is that whoever controls the capital can make profit. Now we all have known from the real cases that even the state owned enterprises with monopoly in its market can lose money year after year.
Of course, this is precisely what the publication he once dismissed as the "premier mouthpiece of the European aristocracy of high finance" would say :P

This is because you lack basic knowledge of the tradition of philosophy that you never escape from your incapacity of understanding Marx's theory and make this silly, shallow comment, you clever "economist".

The automobile industry in China is still heavily protected behind a “tariff wall” even though this wall has come down significantly since China’s entry into the WTO. Cars imported to China face a tariff duty of at least 25 percent. In comparison, American duties on cars imported into the US are only 5 percent. Taking into account the 17 percent of VAT and other levies, imported cars and foreign-brand cars produced in China are substantially more expensive than the same type of cars in the United States.  A new Cadillac SLS made in China will set a Chinese household back between $71,000 and $110,000, without the anti-dumping duty. A better performing Cadillac STS, on the other hand, costs an American household between $47,000 and $56,000.

The gay marriage argument was decided on pretty strong constitutional grounds and it's unlikely to be overturned by any future courts.  Gay marriage isn't going to be banned and Trump has expressed no interest in banning it.

"The primary role of a Supreme Court justice is to faithfully interpret the laws, not to embody an ideology or to satisfy a president’s policy wish." In theory, that's a great statement. In practice, Supreme Court justices are political animals: unelected, unaccountable, no term limit -- but politically biased. Some may be labeled as "liberal", others "conservative."  But they interpret the Constitution in the light of their personal bias and world-view. They may not satisfy a president's wishes, but they certainly might satisfy their personal ideologies.

Did u do any research of the cultural history of this word 'Tong Zhi'? 

Literally it means 'same target/ambition/goal' and it originated from an ancient Chinese classics. It was equally as Xian Sheng (Mister) as a normal address between friends. 

This word was used in modern China by Dr Sun Yat Sen to refer to those revolutionary people. His famous quotes is "革命尚未成功，同志仍需努力”

CCP borrowed this word to refer to those who share the same ideology ( i.e. Communist) among themselves because this word can also be used for both men and women. And Mao and Deng urged people to use this word to address each other instead of by ranks or titles. Thus it symbolised the equity and equality which CCP promoted. 

However it was used to refer to homosexual at HK homosexual film festival in 1989. After that it became an implicit pronoun for gay especially in HK and Taiwan. 

Young Chinese people in mainland gradually abandoned the old meaning of this word in 90s and welcomed the new usage because there were more and more communications between mainland to HK, Taiwan and overseas Chinese community.

Capacity utilization in the US economy is around 75%, so there is some room for demand increase through government spending without inflation taking off dramatically. However, unemployment figures are low in the US and there is talk of a shortage of labor in e.g. the construction sector. This points to wage increase and thus price level rises in the near to mid future. All of this does not pose immediate threats to inflation but the Fed most likely will start to slowly abandon its low interest rate policy to keep inflation expectations in check. Higher interest rates are also necessary to attract foreign investors and borrowers to the US in order to finance Mr Trump's infrastructure spending. So in the medium term I would assume a spike in interest rates and also in inflation (from a rather low base right now). This would also put upward pressure on the US Dollar which already can be seen. If Mr Trump is, in addition to that, pursuing a more protectionist trade policy, then both domestic prices as well as currency value of the US Dollar vis-a-vis the Euro and the Renminbi will increase. US i.e. the US loses competitiveness. Americans will also find that credit financing for e.g. houses will become more expensive. This will then act as a break on consumption and work against the demand impulse from government spending. In the longer term, both effects might cancel each other out and the US economy will have higher price levels but not necessarily more employment. Regardless of that, the competitive position as regards the US Dollar will be weaker unless the ECB and other central banks start to increase their interest rates as well. It will be interesting to watch this economic experiment and observe when and how economic gravity will kick in.

Oregon is a vote by mail state with an outstanding voter information packet, making it quite easy to vote. The motor voter law makes it easier to register to vote.  The big downside in Oregon is that the primaries are closed so voters must be registered with a party to vote in primaries; the ballot measure a couple of years ago to go to open primaries failed.

Oregon's population has increased by about 4% since 2012 (3.899M to 4.087M). Voter turnout increased by about 10% in the same period (1.82M in 2012 and "180,000 more" in 2016).

I'd say that's evidence of the value of automatic voter registration.

The Economist suggests it's a mixed result, but that's because it's using turnout as a percentage of REGISTERED voters instead of as a percentage of ELIGIBLE voters or voting age population or population. 

Turnout as a percentage of registered voters is a terrible way of measuring the effects of restrictive registration regimes because the reduced turnout is baked in.

"But most motor-voters did not choose a party, and only 35% of those voted."  I don't know if the U.S. can fix the participation rate.  Hope they eventually pass open primary.  Better yet, the whole country should do that.

The point is that college produce both knowledge and graduates. The markets for these gods are quite different, while the quality of the producer depends on both. Most degrees will be rendered useless in a few years. This will increase the cost of college and this will cost be pass on to consumers (again government and private sector). High demand is positive, the problem is the supply side. Innovation should not cost a lot of money. Studies with few demand should naturally died out. Another Alleged Transitional Form: Archæopteryx...

According to evolutionists, some small dinosaurs, such as Velociraptors or Dromeosaurs, evolved by acquiring wings and then starting to fly. Thus, Archæopteryx is assumed to be a transitional form that branched off from its dinosaur ancestors and started to fly for the first time. This imaginary tale appears in almost all evolutionist publications.

Evolutionists pronounce the name of one single creature in response. This is the fossil of a bird called Archæopteryx, one of the most widely-known so-called transitional forms among the very few that evolutionists still defend.

rchæopteryx, the so-called ancestor of present-day birds according to evolutionists, lived approximately 150 million years ago. The theory holds that some small dinosaurs, such as Velociraptors or Dromeosaurs, evolved by acquiring wings and then starting to fly. Thus, Archæopteryx is assumed to be a transitional form that branched off from its dinosaur ancestors and started to fly for the first time.

However, the latest studies of Archæopteryx fossils indicate that this creature is absolutely not a transitional form, but an extinct species of bird, having some insignificant differences from present-day birds.

The thesis that Archæopteryx was a "half-bird" that could not fly perfectly was popular among evolutionist circles until not long ago. The absence of a sternum (breastbone) in this creature was held up as the most important evidence that this bird could not fly properly. (The sternum is a bone found under the thorax to which the muscles required for flight are attached. In our day, this breastbone is observed in all flying and non-flying birds, and even in bats, a flying mammal which belongs to a very different family.)

However, the seventh Archæopteryx fossil, which was found in 1992, caused great astonishment among evolutionists. The reason was that in this recently discovered fossil, the breastbone that was long assumed by evolutionists to be missing was discovered to have existed after all. This fossil was described in Nature magazine as follows:

The recently discovered seventh specimen of the Archæopteryx preserves a partial, rectangular sternum, long suspected but never previously documented. This attests to its strong flight muscles.47

This discovery invalidated the mainstay of the claims that Archæopteryx was a half-bird that could not fly properly.

Moreover, the structure of the bird's feathers became one of the most important pieces of evidence confirming that Archæopteryx was a flying bird in the real sense. The asymmetric feather structure of Archæopteryx is indistinguishable from that of birds living today, and indicates that it could fly perfectly well. As the eminent paleontologist Carl O. Dunbar states, "because of its feathers [Archæopteryx is] distinctly to be classed as a bird." 48

Another fact that was revealed by the structure of Archæopteryx's feathers was its warm-blooded metabolism. As was discussed above, reptiles and dinosaurs are cold-blooded animals whose body heat fluctuates with the temperature of their environment, rather than being homeostatically regulated. A very important function of the feathers on birds is the maintenance of a constant body temperature. The fact that Archæopteryx had feathers showed that it was a real, warm-blooded bird that needed to regulate its body heat, in contrast to dinosaurs.

Marx's economic theory, like the work of any other great philosopher past or present, is of course deeply flawed in certain places, some of them crucial to his conclusions. That said, his critique of capitalism is spot on and doesn't depend on anything so esoteric as the densest theoretical chapters of Capital. More people should read him given how quickly global capitalism seems to be careening toward the abyss.

The biggest flaw in his theory is the lack of the concept of risk. Profit is the reward for taking the risk, not from exploitation of the labors. The assumption of Marxism is that whoever controls the capital can make profit. Now we all have known from the real cases that even the state owned enterprises with monopoly in its market can lose money year after year.
Of course, this is precisely what the publication he once dismissed as the "premier mouthpiece of the European aristocracy of high finance" would say :P

Based on certain elements, Capitalism is an amazing, fantastic system, it harness human creativity, has lifted so many people out of poverty...etc. etc  - that said, there is no one entity called capitalism, it has different characteristics at different stages of it's existence. Marx undoubtedly underestimated its resilience, its ability to adapt and do good. Say you turned up really well after your MBA, landing in a 150k+ executive job. Say you like climbing the corporate ladder and love business travelling and an office with a view. (Bear with me)

Isolation need not be a dirty word. Everything goes in a cycle; there is a time for everything, for growth, for rest, for rejuvenate, for reexpansion. A hundred years ago the U.S.A. was in splendid isolation, and that gave it time to deepen its reserves in monies and resources, which then set the stage for it to overtake the world in the aftermath of WW2. Similarly, China was in its own isolation after the communist takeover, and that also created that space for it to grow its strengths within, hence its emergence now. The U.S. cannot sustain a continued bleed on its resources, or it will go the way of the Roman Empire and other empires. Calibrated isolation may be what it truly needs at this moment. Hopefully, Trump will calibrate his policies, and include trade growth approaches for the U.S. in its immediate, regional and global markets.

The automobile industry in China is still heavily protected behind a “tariff wall” even though this wall has come down significantly since China’s entry into the WTO. Cars imported to China face a tariff duty of at least 25 percent. In comparison, American duties on cars imported into the US are only 5 percent. Taking into account the 17 percent of VAT and other levies, imported cars and foreign-brand cars produced in China are substantially more expensive than the same type of cars in the United States.  A new Cadillac SLS made in China will set a Chinese household back between $71,000 and $110,000, without the anti-dumping duty. A better performing Cadillac STS, on the other hand, costs an American household between $47,000 and $56,000.

This word was used in modern China by Dr Sun Yat Sen to refer to those revolutionary people. His famous quotes is "革命尚未成功，同志仍需努力”

CCP borrowed this word to refer to those who share the same ideology ( i.e. Communist) among themselves because this word can also be used for both men and women. And Mao and Deng urged people to use this word to address each other instead of by ranks or titles. Thus it symbolised the equity and equality which CCP promoted. 

However it was used to refer to homosexual at HK homosexual film festival in 1989. After that it became an implicit pronoun for gay especially in HK and Taiwan. 

Young Chinese people in mainland gradually abandoned the old meaning of this word in 90s and welcomed the new usage because there were more and more communications between mainland to HK, Taiwan and overseas Chinese community.

Capacity utilization in the US economy is around 75%, so there is some room for demand increase through government spending without inflation taking off dramatically. However, unemployment figures are low in the US and there is talk of a shortage of labor in e.g. the construction sector. This points to wage increase and thus price level rises in the near to mid future. All of this does not pose immediate threats to inflation but the Fed most likely will start to slowly abandon its low interest rate policy to keep inflation expectations in check. Higher interest rates are also necessary to attract foreign investors and borrowers to the US in order to finance Mr Trump's infrastructure spending. So in the medium term I would assume a spike in interest rates and also in inflation (from a rather low base right now). This would also put upward pressure on the US Dollar which already can be seen. If Mr Trump is, in addition to that, pursuing a more protectionist trade policy, then both domestic prices as well as currency value of the US Dollar vis-a-vis the Euro and the Renminbi will increase. US i.e. the US loses competitiveness. Americans will also find that credit financing for e.g. houses will become more expensive. This will then act as a break on consumption and work against the demand impulse from government spending. In the longer term, both effects might cancel each other out and the US economy will have higher price levels but not necessarily more employment. Regardless of that, the competitive position as regards the US Dollar will be weaker unless the ECB and other central banks start to increase their interest rates as well. It will be interesting to watch this economic experiment and observe when and how economic gravity will kick in.

Oregon is a vote by mail state with an outstanding voter information packet, making it quite easy to vote. The motor voter law makes it easier to register to vote.  The big downside in Oregon is that the primaries are closed so voters must be registered with a party to vote in primaries; the ballot measure a couple of years ago to go to open primaries failed.

Oregon's population has increased by about 4% since 2012 (3.899M to 4.087M). Voter turnout increased by about 10% in the same period (1.82M in 2012 and "180,000 more" in 2016).

I'd say that's evidence of the value of automatic voter registration.

The Economist suggests it's a mixed result, but that's because it's using turnout as a percentage of REGISTERED voters instead of as a percentage of ELIGIBLE voters or voting age population or population. 

Turnout as a percentage of registered voters is a terrible way of measuring the effects of restrictive registration regimes because the reduced turnout is baked in.

"But most motor-voters did not choose a party, and only 35% of those voted."  I don't know if the U.S. can fix the participation rate.  Hope they eventually pass open primary.  Better yet, the whole country should do that.

Globalisation has lifted billions out of poverty. It has created more wealth than has ever been known on earth. It has also shared it more evenly than at any time since before the renaissance (and possibly before classical times).

I suspect that it is that very evenness of sharing, that people in formerly impoverished countries benefit in the numbers of billions from wealth that was formerly concentrated in a few advanced economies in Western Europe, North America and Australasia, and that most global growth has gone to people who were formerly in the bleakest depths of poverty, rather than those who were already relatively wealthy, is in large part responsible for the nationalist, repressive bigotry that seems to have become popular of late.

Numerous possibilities here. Status change after western master countries lost their control of colonies is one. But People's power in western countries (democracy) is major factor. One issue: how skewed might the sample be in the 'emerging world'? Presumably those in such countries who respond to foreign polling companies (online I'd guess) are acutely tuned in to the positive impact globalisation may have had on their countries, and may have benefited disproportionately compared to their fellow countrymen, many of whom perhaps live in more rural communities (in India for example). I'm fairly confident that we'd still see a difference between the various countries polled if the sample were broadened, but that the difference would probably be less marked than it appears here. Obviously, my comment may be moot if I haven't understood YouGov's polling methods and the sample is actually far broader than I've assumed.
